text: English vocabulary lesson 14 topic
connotations part 1
hello everyone if I'm going to help you
learn vocabulary there's something I
should explain and that's the difference
between denotation and connotation if
you want to learn what a word denotes
you can look here in a dictionary you
see denotation is the literal meaning of
a word in a dictionary you're not going
to find connotations a connotation is
what a word suggests it's what's
connected or associated with the word
either emotionally or culturally let's
take for example the word dove a
dictionary will tell you that a dove is
a small white bird
but for many people there's a
connotation of peace because doves are
often chosen as symbols of peace
connotations are very important to
understand you see there are some words
that share the same meaning but suggest
different things so knowing the
connotations can help you choose the
right words let me give you examples
from my own life there are two words
that have caused me some problems
because of their connotations the first
word is skinny
I've been called skinny before and I
admit that I don't like it very much
skinny simply means very thin but the
word has a negative connotation skinny
suggests unhealthy let me look in a
fascist and you'll see what I mean other
words for skinny bony scrawny all of
these words are negative bony all bones
so if someone calls me skinny it makes
me think that when they look at me all
they see are bones that's not attractive
scrawny has a connotation of weakness
you can call a man scrawny if he's so
thin he has no muscles he's weak
so skinny bony scrawny these are very
negative words it would be better to
choose the word thin to describe people
thin has a neutral meaning
in my case I would prefer to be called
slender slender means very thin and it
has a positive connotation slender
suggests thin in a very attractive and
graceful way
the second example concerns the word
guru what is a guru dictionaries will
give two basic definitions one
definition is a person who has a lot of
knowledge in a field an expert
another definition is a spiritual leader
a spiritual guide and I think it's this
definition that is most common
so for over a year now I have hesitated
to call myself guru here on YouTube
because I think for many there's this
connotation of influence and authority
and power I did not want to place myself
in the same category of people who
historically have had a strong influence
over others because of their philosophy
on life
I wish YouTube had another category
called educators but I've come to
realize that there isn't much choice
so recently I've decided to change my
channel type from standard to guru and
it's my hope that you'll accept me as a
YouTube guru and know that in my heart I
remain simply a teacher who doesn't have
all the answers but who has some
knowledge and would like to share that
knowledge with you
let's try an exercise to check your
understanding of some common
connotations exercise 1 choose the word
that best completes each statement
example choose old or elderly you'll use
each word once let's read together it's
not polite to call someone old it's
better to speak of him or her as an
elderly person both words refer to a
person who is no longer young but
elderly has a positive connotation so
it's more polite number 1 choose hard or
challenging read the statement to
yourself and then I'll tell you the
answer answer Owen may quit his job he
is bored at work and wants to find
something more challenging he thinks
with his skills it won't be hard to find
a new job both words mean difficult but
they have different connotations Hart
can suggest frustrating challenging can
suggest interesting to choose
inexpensive or cheap answer I don't have
much money so I need to find an
inexpensive watch but I don't want it to
break after only a month and I don't
want it to look cheap both words mean
not costing much money but cheap has a
negative connotation it can suggest poor
quality 3 choose worried or concerned
answer I forgot to tell my roommate I'd
be out all night she left three messages
on my cell phone in the first she simply
sounded concerned but by the third
message she was definitely worried I
think she was ready to call the police
and have them start a search for me
both words refer to the same feeling
about being interested because you care
but worried is stronger it suggests a
higher level of anxiety being nervous
for choose wife or spouse answer my wife
Anna doesn't like to fill out tax forms
so I do it wherever it says spouse's
signature she just signs her name and
trusts me to do the rest spouse can
refer to husband or wife but this word
has a very formal feeling to it wife and
husband are for everyday use
you wouldn't say let me introduce my
spouse you would say let me introduce my
wife or my husband five choose shy or
modest
answer when the athlete gave short
answers to the reporters questions they
thought he was being modest about his
recent win but the truth is that he
hates cameras and is very shy about
speaking in public both words have
generally the same meaning but shy is
stronger shy can suggest feeling awkward
or uncomfortable with other people or
situation modest simply suggests not
showing too much pride six choose
orchestra or band answer Nick is a
talented performer he can sing and play
music he formed a band with a few
friends
he's the guitarist and lead singer he
also plays the violin in the school
orchestra both words refer to a group of
musicians but band suggests a smaller
number in Orchestra usually suggests
classical music exercise to identify the
false connotation example skinny means
thin it can suggest weak it can suggest
unhealthy it doesn't suggest unfriendly
so the false connotation is see
unfriendly now you try number one fat
not thin the false connotation is C
unimportant - sir a form of address for
a man
the false connotation is handsome a
three pretty attractive the false
connotation is be intelligent for daddy
meaning father the false connotation is
formal daddy in fact is very informal
five pupil student the false connotation
is University pupil can refer to
students in general in a school but not
normally older students 6 but the part
of the body that you sit on the false
connotation is B baby child but is an
informal word and it can be rude so if
you're going to talk about this part of
the body on a baby or child it's better
to use bottom or even bum but not butt
end of part 1 please go on to the next
part of this lesson
